title: Sexual Problems in Women
author: Kathleen Fordyce

content: Sexual dysfunction is a common problem among women. Almost half of all women have persistent problems with sex , such as little or no sex drive, trouble reaching an orgasm , or pain during intercourse.
Satisfying sex involves your body, mind, health, beliefs, and your feelings toward your partner, among other factors. Here are some possible causes behind problems in your sex life.

content_blocks.text: Sexual dysfunction is a common problem among women. Almost half of all women have persistent problems with sex , such as little or no sex drive, trouble reaching an orgasm , or pain during intercourse.
Satisfying sex involves your body, mind, health, beliefs, and your feelings toward your partner, among other factors. Here are some possible causes behind problems in your sex life.

sections.heading: Medical or Physical Conditions
content: Heart disease , diabetes , thyroid disease , nerve conditions such as multiple sclerosis, and even simple fatigue can make sex uncomfortable or painful. They can make it hard for you to get aroused or climax during sex.
Scarring from surgery or radiation treatment in your vaginal opening or in other parts of your genital area also can change your sexual experience. So can infections such as genital herpes .
Other possible causes include hormonal imbalance or physical changes related to:
bullets: Pregnancy (you may have sex less often or find it uncomfortable, especially during the third trimester )
Childbirth (your genitals may be less sensitive, you may have had a difficult delivery)
Breastfeeding (low estrogen levels may lead to vaginal dryness , you may lack energy for sex)

content_blocks.text: Heart disease , diabetes , thyroid disease , nerve conditions such as multiple sclerosis, and even simple fatigue can make sex uncomfortable or painful. They can make it hard for you to get aroused or climax during sex.
Scarring from surgery or radiation treatment in your vaginal opening or in other parts of your genital area also can change your sexual experience. So can infections such as genital herpes .
Other possible causes include hormonal imbalance or physical changes related to:
associated_bullets: Pregnancy (you may have sex less often or find it uncomfortable, especially during the third trimester )
Childbirth (your genitals may be less sensitive, you may have had a difficult delivery)
Breastfeeding (low estrogen levels may lead to vaginal dryness , you may lack energy for sex)

sections.heading: Mental and Emotional Issues
content: The right mood and a healthy, respectful connection with your partner play an important role in sexual intimacy. But there may be factors that leave you feeling self-conscious, fearful, or uninterested. Reasons may include:

content_blocks.text: The right mood and a healthy, respectful connection with your partner play an important role in sexual intimacy. But there may be factors that leave you feeling self-conscious, fearful, or uninterested. Reasons may include:

sections.heading: Medications, Drugs, and Alcohol
content: Drinking can make orgasm longer to achieve or feel less intense. Tobacco smoking and long-term use of heroin and other illegal drugs also can lead to sexual problems.
Some medications can make sex less pleasurable, dampen sex drive, or cause vaginal discomfort. Types of medications include:

content_blocks.text: Drinking can make orgasm longer to achieve or feel less intense. Tobacco smoking and long-term use of heroin and other illegal drugs also can lead to sexual problems.
Some medications can make sex less pleasurable, dampen sex drive, or cause vaginal discomfort. Types of medications include:

sections.heading: Treatments and Other Help
content: See your doctor right away if you suddenly have pain or unusual syptoms during sex, like a headache, or if you think you’ve been exposed to a sexually transmitted disease.

For other kinds of sexual dysfunction, a range of therapies can help. Your doctor will ask about your symptoms, check your health, order blood screens or other tests, and rule out other possible causes.

content: Medical treatments may include:
Other advice to improve your intimate experience may include:
bullets: Drugs to raise low libido (desire for sex)
Kegel exercises to strengthen pelvic muscles to help achieve better orgasm
Anti-inflammatory drugs to take before intercourse to lower pain
More open communication between you and your partner,
Healthy habits , such as minimizing alcohol , getting exercise and eating a healthy diet
Therapy or counseling to help you manage stress or anxiety, or work through feelings of fear or shame in regards to sex
Vaginal lubricant for dryness or lessen pain during sex
Vibrators and other tools to enhance arousal
Techniques on how to reduce distractions and be more present during sex

meta_description: Learn more from WebMD about female sexual problems, including causes, and treatments.
